case_vignette: A 58-year-old man presents with his wife to his primary care physician for an annual check-up. The patient reports that he has been in his usual state of health except for a recent worsening of his seasonal allergies. His wife states that this happens every spring and that his symptoms include sneezing, runny nose, and watery eyes. The wife also asks about a lesion on the patient’s face that she noticed several weeks ago when the patient was wiping his nose. The patient has a history of hypertension and well-controlled diabetes. He takes lisinopril, aspirin, and metformin as prescribed. The patient’s temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 130/78 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 14/min. Physical examination is notable for mild conjunctival injection bilaterally and a nodule located inferior to the left nasal ala, as shown in Figure A.
question: Which  is the best therapy for the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having worse sneezing, a runny nose, and watery eyes lately.
When did these symptoms begin?
They started getting worse recently with my seasonal allergies every spring.
Have you experienced these symptoms in previous years during spring?
Yes, this happens to me every spring.
Are you currently taking any medication for your allergies?
No, I haven't mentioned taking any medication for my allergies.
Do these symptoms improve when you are indoors or away from areas with a lot of pollen?
You didn't ask about that, so I don't have any information to share about whether my symptoms improve indoors or away from pollen.
Do these symptoms improve when you go indoors or avoid areas with high pollen counts?
My symptoms are related to my seasonal allergies, so they probably do get better when I'm indoors or away from pollen.
Final Diagnosis: Seasonal Allergic Rhinitis (Hay Fever)
